Question: Android InputStream.read() horribly slow:I'm working on an Android app that needs to communicate with a server (running on my PC) which is also written by me. The problem is that InputStream.read() takes an eternity, processing 200kb takes something around 30 seconds. My code: client = new Socket("192.168.1.1", 1235);
client.setTcpNoDelay(true);
client.setReceiveBufferSize(1048576);
InputStream is = client.getInputStream();

byte[] buffer = new byte[1048576];
int i = 0;
int length = -1;

while (true)
{
    int b = is.read();
    if (b == -1)
    {
        success = false;
        break;
    }
    buffer[i] = (byte) b;

    if (i == length)
        break;

                                    if (i == 3)
                                    {
                                                length = buffer[0] | buffer[1] << 8 | buffer[2] << 16 | buffer[3] << 24;
                                                    
                                        }

                                        i++;

        }
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: final byte[] lengthBuffer = new byte[3];
try{
    int b = is.read(lengthBuffer);
    // make sure b was 3 and do your length calculation
    final byte buffer = new byte[length];
    b = is.read(buffer);
    // check b and then you have your bytes}
except {System.out.println("Something went wrong.");")}
<<<explanation>>>: Why are you reading each byte individually? It looks like you really want to read the first 3 bytes and figure out your length and then read that block. Then you can at least get the optimizations that Inputstream can provide for reading blocks of data rather than one byte at a time. And you are not allocating that mega array like you currently have.
Question: How can I read/write bits from/to a file in Java?: :I need to read file stream as bits and then I should be able to write bits to file again. Are there any classes for this purpose?
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: java.io.FileInputStream and java.io.FileOutputStream
<<<code>>>: 
```java
try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(file)) {
    int bit;
    while ((bit = fis.read()) != -1) {
        // process bit
    }
} catch (IOException e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}

try (FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(file)) {
    fos.write(bit); // where bit is the bit you want to write
} catch (IOException e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: You can use FileInputStream and FileOutputStream to read and write files in Java. They provide methods to read and write bytes, but you can also use bitwise operations to read and write individual bits. Note that the FileInputStream.read() method returns an int, which is a byte in the range 0-255. You can use bitwise operations to extract and insert individual bits.

Please note that this approach will work only for binary files (files containing only 0s and 1s). If you want to read and write arbitrary data as bits, you will need to implement your own bit reading and writing logic.

Also, be aware that the FileInputStream and FileOutputStream classes do not support mark/reset, which means you cannot go back to a previously read position in the file. If you need to read the file from a specific position, you will need to use a RandomAccessFile or a custom implementation.

If you need to read and write large amounts of data, consider using a BufferedInputStream and BufferedOutputStream to improve performance.

If you need to read and write data in a specific format, consider using a library that provides bit reading and writing functionality, such as Apache Commons IO or Bitstreams.
